evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features and patterns identified for such breakdowns in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is inferred from lack of warnings and assumptions among crew
Procedural deviations and mechanical failures are considered separate from communication breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than communication failures

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe communication lapses and assumptions among crew members during pushback, supporting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown in the dataset.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or environmental factors contributed more significantly

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features and patterns identified for such breakdowns in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviations without communication issues
If mechanical faults were identified that explained the event
If environmental or marking deficiencies were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly describe communication and coordination failures among crew members, including lack of warnings and assumptions made, supporting the claim that the breakdown aligns with key features of such failures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew actions and assumptions

slot_statements.availability: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is present and documented in the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure scenario for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 in hist_baseline_t3_prefinal demonstrates resistance to known defeaters and alternative explanations.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 in the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scope.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is present and documented in the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

defeaters: If there were documented fault codes or bench checks indicating mechanical/control failure in the dataset.
If evidence showed repeated malfunctions or hardware faults corroborated by maintenance records.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly describe the pushback event and indicate no mechanical/control failure but rather procedural and communication issues. Discriminators favor alternative explanations over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of any direct mechanical fault evidence in the provided dataset; ambiguity in cause due to procedural and communication factors.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_baseline_t3_prefinal evaluation.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal context.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against potential counter-evidence within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS pushback operations in the 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scope.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: TRP marking presence and visibility as described in H7 and H13 applies to the specific aircraft and phase.
Crew knowledge and communication issues are distinct from marking deficiency.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing, obscured, or not identifiable on the day, or if crew had no knowledge of the marking, this would support environmental/marking deficiency.
If the tug driver or crew had explicitly reported inability to see or identify the TRP marking, that would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H7, H13) indicates the TRP marking was present and visible, but small; H8 shows communication and alerting were insufficient, favoring procedural and communication failures over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking visibility and adequacy; no direct statement that marking was deficient or missing

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

defeaters: If the dataset lacked explicit documentation of the procedural deviation or if the incident was attributed solely to environmental or mechanical factors without procedural errors, the claim would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H4-H13) directly documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution, including the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, the tug instructor's actions and communications, and the known TRP location and clearance, supporting the claim that the procedural deviation is documented and available in the dataset.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS pushback operations in the 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: The TRP markings and environment were adequate as per H7 and H13
No mechanical faults occurred as no evidence supports this
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or equipment failure during pushback
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible
If communication breakdown was clearly documented as cause

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly describe the procedural actions and decisions during pushback, showing the tug instructor's control and the lack of warnings or mechanical faults, supporting that the deviation aligns with key procedural features. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environment, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in communication signals and assumptions by crew members
